<topcClas>Social indicators and quality of life - Society and culture</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The <i>National Survey for Wales</i> (NSW) is a major study conducted by the Welsh Government. The NSW is one of the main ways in which the Welsh Government knows what issues are important to the people of Wales. A pilot study was completed in 2009-2010 and main stage fieldwork on the survey started in January 2012. The NSW will run continuously to at least 2015. TNS-BRMB and Beaufort Research Ltd have commissioned by the Welsh Government to carry out the survey fieldwork.  The final dataset is based on a representative sample across Wales, ensuring balanced sampling across each local authority.  The survey involves conducting more than 14,000 25-minute face-to-face interviews with a randomly selected representative sample of people aged 16 and over across Wales per year (approximately 660 interviews in each local authority). Fieldwork is based on a random probability sample design and is conducted on a continuous basis. The information collected will be used to inform the development of policy and the delivery of public services.<br> <br> The NSW has replaced the <i>Living in Wales</i> survey series (available from the UK Data Archive under GN 33397). Further information is available on the Welsh Government <a href="http://wales.gov.uk/about/aboutresearch/social/ocsropage/nationalsurveyforwales/?lang=en" title ="National Survey for Wales">National Survey for Wales</a> web pages.<br> </abstract>       <abstract>The aim of the <i>National Survey for Wales, 2009-2010: Pilot Study</i> was to test the survey design, but also to provide valuable information for the Welsh Assembly Government on a range of issues.  The pilot survey was based on face-to-face interviews in a randomly chosen sample of households across Wales. In each of these households, the survey covered the head of household and a randomly selected adult (who may also be the head of household). There was also a short self-completion questionnaire for every adult in the household.<br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>The household questionnaire covers:<ul><li>housing tenure</li><li>housing costs</li><li>financial inclusion</li><li>accommodation problems</li><li>household deprivation</li><li>children's deprivation</li><li>internet access</li><li>pet ownership</li></ul>The individual questionnaire covers:<ul><li>neighbourhood</li><li>communications</li><li>disability</li><li>environmental behaviour</li><li>computer and internet</li><li>Welsh Assembly Government</li><li>street cleaning</li><li>dental practices</li><li>volunteering</li><li>employment</li><li>finance</li></ul>The self-completion questionnaire covers: <ul><li>health</li><li>local public services</li><li>satisfaction with aspects of life</li><li>local area</li><li>safety and crime</li><li>harassment and discrimination</li></ul>A sample file is also included which contains geographical information about all the sampled households (including non-responding households).<br> <br> <i>Standard Measures:</i><br> The Rosenberg Scale was included in the self-completion questionnaire.  Scores on the scale were derived from a series of ten questions which asked respondents to indicate whether they agreed or disagreed with a series of statements regarding their general feelings about themselves.</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <timePrd event="start" date="2009-10-01T00:00:00Z">October 2009</timePrd>         <timePrd event="end" date="2010-07-01T00:00:00Z">July 2010</timePrd>         <collDate>Fieldwork for the survey was carried out in two stages: between October 2009 and April 2010; and then, following amendments to the design, between May and July 2010.</collDate>         <nation>Wales</nation>         <geogUnit>Unitary Authorities (Wales)</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Westminster Parliamentary Constituencies</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Welsh National Assembly Electoral Regions</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>Individuals aged 16 or over living in private households in Wales, 2009-2010.</universe>         <dataKind>Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Repeated cross-sectional study</timeMeth>         <dataCollector>CELLO mruk Social and Market Research</dataCollector>         <sampProc>See documentation for details</sampProc>         <deviat>Household file: 4,559 cases; Individual file: 6,386 cases; Self Completion file: 3,331 cases; Sample file: 14,124 cases</deviat>         <collMode>Face-to-face interview; Self-completion</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>Weighting used. See documentation for details</weight>         <cleanOps>A</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Standard conditions of access</specPerm>         <restrctn>The depositor has specified that registration is required and standard conditions of use apply.
